thread.title: Alzheimer's Disease Potentially Transmitted via Contaminated Surgical Instruments
thread.title_full: Alzheimer's Disease Potentially Transmitted via Contaminated Surgical Instruments

author: Rebecca Rudolph, Editor, Surgical Products
title: Alzheimer's Disease Potentially Transmitted via Contaminated Surgical Instruments
text:
A study suggests Alzheimer's disease is transmittable during certain medical procedures, including during surgery, by attaching onto instruments. These results were published in Nature after researchers performed autopsies on eight patients who died of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD).
There is no proven treatment for CJD, a rare but fatal neurodegenerative condition, but the eight patients, ranging in ages from 36 to 51, received growth hormones extracted from the pituitary glands of human cadavers. During the autopsy, the researchers found something troubling - six of the eight had early indications of Alzheimers. Before presenting their results, researchers looked for evidence indicating another explanation for the symptoms. They determined that the patients didn't carry genes that would predispose them to Alzhermer's.
Researchers say this is troubling, because, while there isn't any indication that it can be transmitted through normal contact with patients, it could be passed on through contact with human growth hormones, such as blood transfusions or contaminated surgical instruments - much like Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.
Scientists are preparing to try to replicate the results independently to verify this find.
